sample_analysed_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"In the present study, to evaluate the effectiveness of these two intervention programs, we randomly sampled 76 children (38 in each intervention group) from the four intervention preschools. In addition, we sampled 24 children from two other untreated preschools to serve as a control group.We administered pretests to the 76 children sampled from the intervention preschools (38 children in each of the two intervention programs), but only 71 of these children completed the posttest measures (36 children in the joint writing program and 35 in joint reading)."
"All 24 children in the
control group completed measures at both the pretest and posttest intervals.[¬e]"']
fsm_info_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"Participants comprised preschoolers from six preschools in the low SES township of Jaffa in cen-
tral Israel.[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"Jaffa residents face a lack
of education and health programs, a high level of violence and crime, a number of neighborhoods
known for drug dealing, and a high percentage of multiproblem families who suffer from domestic
violence, economic distress, poor health, single parenthood, etc. The unemployment rate is higher than
the general rate in Israel, and 30.1% of Jaffa’s residents regularly receive local welfare services, in
comparison with 16.3% in Tel Aviv. The rate of persons per room in Jaffa (1.53) surpasses that of
Tel Aviv (0.87). The rate of single mothers in Jaffa (17.7%) is higher than the general rate in Israel
(10.0%).[¬e]"']
base_n_treat_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"In the present study, to evaluate the effectiveness of these two intervention programs, we randomly\nsampled 76 children (38 in each intervention group) from the four intervention preschools[¬e]"']

fsm_info_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"Researchers recruited through the local community leaders families
that had a child between the ages 3 and 6 years old. Families were
paid US$10 for time and effort involved in participating ($4 at base-
line and $6 at post-intervention). At baseline, researchers inter-
viewed 160 children and 160 parents. Fifty-four families were
from Kota Dukuh, 53 from Munjul, and 53 from Gunung. After the
intervention, researchers were able to re-contact and re-interview
ALL the children and parents.[¬e]"']
base_n_cont_ht:
['Page 7:
[¬s]"54 in the
Results
Demographic and household information
Basic information about the sample appears in Table 1. At the start
of the experiment, the children were on average 4.9 years old,
ranging in age from 3.5 to 6 years old. According to the parents,
100 children (62.5%) attended some sort of school. Demographic
variables did not differ in a statistically significant way across the
three villages where data collection occurred.
All participants came from low-income households, and access
to resources was limited. Table 2 presents information on
ownership of different household items. We did not observe any
statistically significant differences in resource access across the
three villages. While we observed increasing trends, those households
where an adult had higher levels ofeducation did not have statistically
significant greater access to resources and items.
Media use
According to the parents, all participatingchildrenwatched television;
2% watched one day a week, 22% two to six days a week, and 76%
every day or almost every day a week. When asked where their child
usually watched, 80%said home, 18% said a neighbor’s house, and
2%a relative’s house. Around 19%ofthe parents said they watched
alongside their childrenmost ofthe time, 71%someofthe time, and
11% none of the time. Parents estimated, on average, that their
children watched 12.6 hours of television per week (SD ¼ 9.5,
range 1 to 45 hours). While boys watched more that girls (an aver-
age of 13.8 hours compared to an average of 11.6 hours), this dif-
ference was not statistically significant. We did not observe any
relationship between child’s age and estimated number of hours
watched per week. The level of education completed by the adult
household member was associated with estimated number of tele-
vision hours watched by the child (F¼ 4.0, df¼ 3, 157, p <0.01);
those who lived in households where the highest level ofeducation
control[¬e]"']

fsm_perc_ht:
['Page 11:
[¬s]"To be eligible, a center had to: serve primarily low-income children (75% or more eligible for free-and
reduced-price meals in the CACFP), including some whose care was subsidized; and have at least one four-
year-old classroom with at least five children.[¬e]"']
attri_ht:
['Page 16:
[¬s]"Over the course of two years, seven centers left the study. Five left because the
center was closed or sold to an owner who chose not to participate; only two left because the director
decided not to continue with the curriculum to which they were assigned. While, in spite of the
incentives offered, teachers did leave and were replaced, our concern was about the attrition of
centers, since they were the unit of random assignment. Center attrition, as we have seen, was very
low and distributed quite evenly across the four groups.[¬e]"']
attri_info: Unclear if from control or intervention groups

fsm_info_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"Suffolk County, the easternmost of the two counties that con-
stitute Long Island, has a population of 1.3 million. Although
sections of the north shore of the county and the east end are
among the most affluent in the nation, the center of the county and
some areas of the south shore include large populations living in
conditions of poverty. Living costs, particularly housing costs, are
very high. The median reported family income of children attend-
ing Head Start in Suffolk County, New York during the 1992-
1993 year was $10,500, as determined by Head Start records.[¬e]"']
attri_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"Another 40 children were included in the sample at the outset but left Head Start prior to the end of the school year and could not be posttested. These children scored significantly lower on the battery of pretest assessments than the 167 children who com- pleted the entire year. Differences between the dropouts of the intervention condition (N = 15) and control condition (N = 25) on a principal component weighted average of all the pretest assess- ments (described in more detail subsequently) did not approach statistical significance (p = .938)."
"Six additional children who otherwise met the criteria for par- ticipation in the study were excluded from the research design because they were unable to produce any expressive responses in English on the pretest battery. Five of these children were mono- lingual in a language other than English (3 Spanish, 1 Arabic, 1 Hindi), and one child from an English-speaking home was elec- tively mute."
"ondition and 97 in the control
condition. Because of the higher frequency of dropout from the
control classrooms, the final Ns were more disparate (intervention

sample_analysed_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]"Seventy-three 3-year-olds from low-income families participated in\nthis research.[¬e]"']
fsm_info_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]"Seventy-three 3-year-olds from low-income families participated in
this research"
"The enrollees
of the day-care centers used in this study consisted predominantly of
children whose parents qualified for public subsidy of day-care costs
under Title XX of the Federal Social Security Act. In Suffolk County
the maximum allowable family income for a Title XX subsidy was ap-
proximately $24,000 at the time of this study, with the limit varying
somewhat depending on family size. Because living costs, and particu-
larly housing costs, are high in Suffolk County, families at that income
level could be described as the working poor.[¬e]"']

sample_analysed_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]"Seventy-three 3-year-olds from low-income families participated in\nthis research[¬e]"']
fsm_info_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]"The enrollees
of the day-care centers used in this study consisted predominantly of
children whose parents qualified for public subsidy of day-care costs
under Title XX of the Federal Social Security Act. In Suffolk County
the maximum allowable family income for a Title XX subsidy was ap-
proximately $24,000 at the time of this study, with the limit varying
somewhat depending on family size. Because living costs, and particu-
larly housing costs, are high in Suffolk County, families at that income
level could be described as the working poor.[¬e]"']

['Page 4:
[¬s]"As all participants' families qualified for admission into Head Start,
all lived below the federal poverty level. Suffolk County, New
York, where this study was conducted, has among the highest
housing costs and the highest utility costs in the nation. It is a
suburban setting in which jobs and services are dispersed over a
wide geographical area, but it has very limited public transporta-
tion. As a result of these factors, low-income families are particu-
larly stressed economically.[¬e]"']
attri_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]"Children whose data were included in the analyses conducted in
the present study were (a) within one of the Head Start classrooms
that was randomly assigned to the intervention or control condition
during their cohort year; (b) eligible by birth date for entry into
public kindergarten during the year following Head Start; (c) tested
at pretest at the beginning of Head Start, posttest at the end of Head
Start, and follow-up at the end of kindergarten; and (d) had a
language quotient of no more than 105 at pretest on the Peabody
Picture Vocabulary Test—Revised (PPVT; Dunn & Dunn, 1981)
in order to maintain balance between conditions, as explained
subsequently."
"The imposition of these selection conditions resulted in the
exclusion of 74 children who had participated in the intervention
study during Head Start. Of these, 53 were lost to follow-up
between the end of Head Start and the end of kindergarten, and 21
were excluded because they had language quotients greater than
105 at pretest"
"We excluded the children lost to follow-up because one of our
principal questions was whether effects of the intervention would
be maintained through the end of kindergarten."
"We excluded children with pretest language quotients greater
than 105 to deal with an imbalance in pretest scores that occurred
across the intervention and control condition[¬e]"', 'Page 4:
[¬s]"As chance would have it, more children with high scores were found in the intervention classrooms than in the control classrooms."
"However, because of differential attrition, the
imbalance in pretest scores became statistically significant for the
children who survived in the study until the end of kindergarten:
Only 5% of high scorers were lost to follow-up at kindergarten,
whereas 16% of children with lower pretest scores were lost to
follow-up. This probably reflects a correlation between children's
pretest scores and variables affecting family functioning, such that
children with lower scores were more likely to be in circumstances
in which they experienced changes in housing and geography that
led us to be unable to find them in kindergarten. The problem of
imbalance between conditions in pretest scores c[¬e]"']
attri_info: We don't know initial number assigned. various attrition factors are described - but a specific exact % cannot be taken as absolute due to all these factors
